Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Role of Housing Stakeholders in the Recovery of the U.S. Housing Market

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ms. Elizabeth Youngling, under the supervision of Dr. Andrew Orta of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign will explore how networks of stakeholders work to redeem values diminished by economic crisis. In the wake of the mortgage crisis, the project asks how variously positioned housing stakeholders (realtors, mortgage bankers, housing counselors, and homeowners) come together to redeem the social and economic value of homeownership in the post-2008 economic environment. The research will be conducted in Chicago, Illinois, a city still struggling with the long-term effects of the mortgage crisis. Focusing on the daily practices of housing professionals and the homeowners they serve, the researcher will conduct twelve months of research at key sites in the production and promotion of homeownership: mortgage banks, realty offices, and housing organizations. Her research methods will include semi-structured interviews, participant observation, focus groups, and textual analysis of documents related to the history of homeownership in the United States since the Great Depression.

By framing the housing market as a meeting point for different values, interests, and scales of action, the research explores the intersections between macro-level financial processes and their micro-level effects. The study will contribute to scholarship on the political and cultural economies of homeownership, social mobility, holistic understandings of social and economic value, and role of economic institutions in shaping everyday life. The broader impact of the project lies in its attention to the post-crisis reproduction and transformation of the U.S. housing market, which has been an essential component of U.S. economic prosperity and social mobility for over half a century. The research will inform our understanding of the inner workings of a key dimension of the U.S economy and society during a period of cultural, political, and economic change. The results will be made available to academic, practitioner, and general audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined a network of housing stakeholders (realtors, mortgage lenders, real estate developers and investors, housing policymakers, counselors, and organizers, and current and prospective homeowners) active in the recovery of the U.S. housing market in the wake of the mortgage crisis.  In exploring how these variously positioned actors came together to redeem the value of homeownership in the post-2008 economic environment, it addressed the taken-for-granted social and economic goods associated with the instituton of homeownership, the role and impact of public and private support and funding for pro-homeownership initiatives, and the varied results of national, state, and local housing market recovery efforts. 

 Under the supervision of Dr. Andrew Orta, Ms. Elizabeth Youngling conducted the research for this project in Chicago, Illinois, a city still struggling with the long-term effects of the mortgage crisis. Focusing on the daily practices of a network of housing stakeholders active in some of the city’s hardest hit neighborhoods, she conducted interviews with seventy-eight individuals, engaged in participant observation at a number of the housing industry’s key sites, and analyzed both the projected and actual results of national and local foreclosure prevention and housing market recovery programs. 

The outcomes of Ms. Youngling’s research include an understanding of the patchwork of public and private incentives and interests that help produce robust housing recoveries in some markets and fail to do so in others. Her project’s findings illuminate the ways in which the continued celebration and support of homeownership as a universal social and economic good in the United States can unwittingly reproduce inequalities that divide communities by class, housing tenure, race and ethnicity, and socioeconomic opportunity.   Ms. Youngling’s research also yields important information on the impact of increased federal scrutiny, compensation restrictions, and technological change on two key sets of actors in the housing industry: real estate brokers and mortgage lenders.  She found that in spite of real estate brokers and lenders’ firsthand understanding of the costs and consequences of the housing market’s boom and bust, their desire for a free market environment and their own professional autonomy sometimes placed them in conflict with the very structures intended to support their industry's steady recovery.

The outcomes of Ms. Youngling’s research also make contributions to social scientific understandings of markets, regimes of social and economic value, and housing and homeownership.  By focusing on social, economic, and political processes and networks rather than to a specific site or group, the project makes methodological strides by adding to the ways in which we study and analyze complex social problems. Ms. Youngling’s research informs our understanding of the inner workings of a key dimension of the U.S economy and society during a period of cultural, political, and economic change.
